The tech has gotten even better since this video. There is the Freestyle Libra sensor. It’s tiny disc, containing a tiny needle (capillary sized). You attach it to the diabetics arm (sits on the skin), and it will constantly monitor blood sugar levels over days and send the data to your smart phone. I believe the sensor only lasts 3 days, but I can imagine in a decade or 2 it could last months or a year. Although the needle will have to be changed for an alternative access for it to last longer. You don’t need an insulin pump and machine with an implant to access constant measurement anymore. Mild to moderate type 2 diabetics can access this tech. Preventing the progression of diabetes is so important and newer tech is making it even easier.

The three types of diabetes you mentioned are the most common, but you did miss a few the more rare ones:

Type 2: Can be roughly divided into primary insulin resistance, and primary insulin deficiency without another known cause. The latter subtype is rare, and generally needs insulin therapy very early on.

Type 3: Something Alzheimer's related. Not sure on the details and this designation as a separate type of diabetes is considered controversial among doctors.

Type 3c: Removal of, or extensive injury to, the pancreas. Usually happens in pancreatic cancer patients.

CFRD: Cystic Fibrosis Related Diabetes. Related to Cystic Fibrosis, of course.

MODY: Maturity Onset Diabetes of the Young. A very old, and confusing name for what is also called Monogenic Diabetes. There are a few types, but they're all purely genetic, and we've pretty much mapped out the exact gene for each type of MODY. Some types require insulin, others respond well to oral medications in a way similar to Type 2.

LADA: Latent Autoimmune Diabetes in Adults. It's Type 1, but slower. Generally only medically detectable after age 30. Sometimes also has insulin resistance come along for the ride. The slow progression, plus the sometimes-present insulin resistance means Type 2 medications often work, until the pancreatic damage gets to be too extensive and then insulin therapy is required. Often misdiagnosed as Type 2, sometimes tragically. This designation is also controversial. Some doctors think LADA should just be lumped in with Type 1 without any special descriptors, others believe treating it as a separate thing is useful for determining the correct course of treatment. Sometimes colloquially referred to as Type 1.5.

Hemochromatosis: Okay, technically this just a known cause for some forms of Type 2, but worth calling out separately since the mechanism by which it works is actually pretty well understood.

There are also some other steroid therapy related forms of "sort-of" diabetes that aren't really considered as such as long as they resolve completely when the steroid therapy is concluded.

So three years on, I have some interesting news for Diabetes sugar level testing. Its a very short cylinder, with a needle, and sensor on one side, that goes into the arm, and constantly monitors blood sugar levels, as the sugar passes through the skin. The sensors and monitors on the inside of the device attached to the arm, wirelessly transmit the data to a small hand held device, that can also scan the device on the arm, to get an accurate reading of the sugar levels at that point. The biggest pros to this technology is that it eliminates the finger prick test, almost completely as it is still used by hospitals, and this device can monitor sugar levels over night, giving a view of what happens all the time. I recommend looking at the FreeStyle Libre website for a better and more detailed description of this.

After 10 years of no diabetes but still tested as Pre Diabetic i designed an experiment to measure the accuracy and precision of the measurement system. Whem compared to international standards the system failed. My endocrinilogist explained it's just a guideline.

The probability of developing diabetes wirhin 5 years of being diagnosised as prediabetic is abot 30%. After 20 years thst probability drops to close to nil.

Ketones and ketoacids are alternative fuels for the body that are made when glucose is in short supply. They are made in the liver from the breakdown of fats. Ketones are formed when there is not enough sugar or glucose to supply the body’s fuel needs. This occurs overnight, and during dieting or fasting. This happens if your a type 1 like me or not. Also ketones exponentially raise blood sugar if aloud to stay in you especially when exercising. so pushing fluids is necessary for diabetics to flush the ketones out asap.

Personal insulin pumps have been around for quite a long time actually. My mother first got one around 15 years ago. They used to be almost completely manual where you have to calculate the amount of insulin based on carbohydrate intake. Now she  Medtronic pump she has continuously monitors blood sugar and delivers insulin as needed. It wirelessly connects to a separate display for control and will anticipate the patterns, lag and lead of the body's blood sugar levels. The 'electronic pancreas' allows one to go from having to check blood sugar and having insulin shots three times a day to basically forgetting about it until you have to change the reservoir every few days.
